# Hong Kong's Status as an International Financial Center

Hong Kong maintains its position as a global offshore RMB business hub. Last year’s tax reforms helped create a favorable environment to attract multinational corporations to establish corporate treasury centers in Hong Kong. To develop Hong Kong into an infrastructure financing center and a fintech hub, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority established the Infrastructure Financing Facilitation Office and the Fintech Facilitation Office during the year. The HKMA issued 13 licenses to stored value payment tool issuers during the year. Hong Kong’s sound fiscal performance and substantial net foreign assets continue to be confirmed by credit rating agencies, with Standard & Poor’s maintaining its AAA rating for Hong Kong.

# Overview

Affected by global financial market volatility and uncertainty over the RMB exchange rate outlook, offshore RMB business slowed down globally in 2016. Nevertheless, Hong Kong maintained its position as the global offshore RMB business hub, processing approximately seven out of ten RMB payment transactions globally. The Shenzhen-Hong Kong Stock Connect, launched in December, marked another milestone in China's capital account opening and represented an important step in enhancing Hong Kong's status as an international financial center. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority also strengthened financial infrastructure by expanding RMB liquidity support to the market and introducing measures to increase the transparency of RMB market liquidity.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) established the Infrastructure Financing Facilitation Office (IFFO) in July to promote infrastructure development by bringing together key stakeholders and to develop Hong Kong into a hub for infrastructure financing. As of the end of January 2017, more than 60 institutions had joined IFFO as partners. During the year, the HKMA also successfully pushed through legislative amendments to eliminate tax asymmetries and provide tax incentives, encouraging multinational and mainland companies to establish corporate treasury centers in Hong Kong, thereby creating more business opportunities for the financial and professional services sectors. The number of institutional investors operating in Hong Kong has also been gradually increasing. Among them, the Abu Dhabi Investment Authority, the world's third-largest sovereign fund, announced in October the establishment of an overseas office in Hong Kong, which is the only office located outside of Abu Dhabi.

The International Monetary Fund (IMF) gave a positive assessment of our commitment to consolidating Hong Kong’s position as an international financial center during last year’s Article IV consultation discussions. This year, the HKMA has actively participated in international discussions, striving to promote global and regional financial stability. The HKMA has also maintained close communication with international credit rating agencies, work that helped Hong Kong’s credit ratings to be affirmed by major credit rating agencies in 2016.

The safe and effective operation and continued development of Hong Kong’s financial infrastructure play a vital role in consolidating Hong Kong’s competitiveness as an international financial center and a global hub for offshore RMB business. The four real-time gross settlement (RTGS) systems for interbank transactions and the Central Securities Clearing System (CMU) achieved 100% system availability in 2016, exceeding the target level of 99.95%.

The HKMA further strengthened Hong Kong's retail payment financial infrastructure in 2016. During the year, a total of 13 stored value facility licenses were issued in accordance with the Payment Systems and Stored Value Facilities Ordinance (the "Payment Ordinance"), which came into full effect in November 2016. The scope of electronic cheque services has also been extended to cross-border payments between Hong Kong and Guangdong Province (including Shenzhen).

To promote the development of Hong Kong's fintech industry, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) established the Fintech Facilitation Office in March. Several key initiatives implemented this year have made satisfactory progress.

The Monetary Authority has introduced a series of measures to strengthen the soft power of the banking industry, including (i) launching a program to enhance the professional capabilities of directors; (ii) establishing an overall professional qualification framework for banking practitioners across the industry; and (iii) implementing a consumer education program.

# 2016 Retrospective

# Offshore Renminbi Business

The volatility in global financial markets in 2016 and the uncertainty in the outlook for the RMB exchange rate led to a slowdown in offshore RMB activities. As of the end of the year, the combined balance of RMB customer deposits and deposit certificates in Hong Kong amounted to 625.1 billion RMB, a 38% decrease compared to the previous year (Figure 1). The issuance of offshore RMB bonds during the year dropped to 52.8 billion RMB, and the amount of RMB trade settlements processed through Hong Kong banks also declined to 45,421 billion RMB. On the other hand, the balance of RMB loans held by Hong Kong banks as of the end of the year was 2,948 billion RMB, similar to the previous year (Figure 2). The transaction volume of the RMB RTGS system remained at a high level, with an average daily processing volume of 8,636 billion RMB in 2016. This shows that although the RMB funding pool has shrunk, it continues to support a significant amount of RMB financial intermediation activities in Hong Kong. According to statistics from SWIFT, Hong Kong handled about 70% of RMB payment transactions in 2016, which demonstrates Hong Kong's position as the global offshore RMB business hub.

Within the year, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) worked closely with relevant mainland authorities to secure greater policy space for developing RMB business in Hong Kong. Several new measures were introduced during the year, including further expanding the opening-up of the mainland interbank bond market and foreign exchange market, as well as launching the "Shenzhen-Hong Kong Stock Connect" in December. In response to increased demand for cross-border investment channels and liquidity management, the HKMA expanded its RMB liquidity arrangements. In October, the HKMA increased the number of primary liquidity providers from seven to nine, and the total quota of the arrangement was also raised from 14 billion RMB to 18 billion RMB. The HKMA also enhanced the transparency of its RMB liquidity arrangements, helping participating banks more effectively manage their liquidity.

The national "13th Five-Year Plan," published in March, reaffirmed Hong Kong's status as the global offshore RMB business hub, demonstrating the central government's support for Hong Kong to further develop its offshore RMB business.

At the same time, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) continues to strengthen cooperation with other economies to develop offshore RMB business. The HKMA is also actively participating in various activities to promote Hong Kong's role as the global offshore RMB hub and as a key platform for China's "going global" strategy. These activities include participating in local events organized by industry groups and private institutions, as well as overseas events in mainland China, Germany, Kazakhstan, and the United Kingdom.

# Closer Economic Partnership Arrangement between the Mainland and Hong Kong

The new agreement under the Closer Economic Partnership Arrangement (CEPA) between the Mainland and Hong Kong, regarding the substantial liberalization of trade in services, was signed in 2015. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority continues to closely monitor the implementation of measures under the current arrangement and collaborates with government authorities to explore further expanding market access and facilitating measures for Hong Kong’s financial sector in the Mainland market.

# Infrastructure Financing Facilitation Office (IFFO)

# IFFO’s mission

IFFO’s mission is to promote infrastructure investment and financing by bringing together key stakeholders. IFFO’s functions are:
- To provide a platform for information exchange and experience sharing;
- To enhance skills and knowledge in infrastructure investment and financing;
- To promote market and product development;
- And to facilitate infrastructure investment and financing activities.

Eddie Yue, Chief Executive of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (seventh from the left), toasting with other guests at the IFFO launch ceremony.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority established IFFO in July, with the mission of promoting infrastructure investment and financing by bringing together key stakeholders. As of the end of January 2017, more than 60 institutions from mainland China, Hong Kong, and overseas had joined IFFO as partners, including multilateral financial institutions and development banks, public sector investors, private sector investors, asset management companies, banks, insurance companies, infrastructure project developers and operators, professional service firms, and international trade associations (Table 1).

Since its establishment, IFFO has made steady progress. To enhance skills, IFFO organized an executive workshop in October, co-hosted with the International Finance Corporation (IFC) and Hanwha Investment & Securities, focusing on "private participation in infrastructure project finance in emerging markets." The workshop received very positive feedback, helping participants gain knowledge and build networks. In November, IFFO held a senior executive seminar, inviting Mr. Jin Liqun, President of the Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank, to speak and share his experience in infrastructure project planning, operation, and management. In July, IFFO signed Memorandums of Understanding with the International Finance Corporation and the Global Infrastructure Center, establishing a cooperation framework. In December, IFFO also signed Memorandums of Understanding with the China Development Bank and the China Export-Import Bank, leveraging the IFFO platform to facilitate infrastructure financing for these two banks. These activities have helped strengthen Hong Kong's position and international reputation as an infrastructure financing hub.

The Financial Services and Markets Commission Chairman Mr. Chen Der-lin (left) and World Bank Group Executive Vice President and CEO Philippe Le Houerou (right) signed Memorandums of Understanding, facilitating cooperation through the IFFO platform to create a more efficient and favorable market environment for regional infrastructure investment and financing.

The Financial Services and Markets Commission Chairman Mr. Chen Der-lin (left) and Global Infrastructure Hub CEO Mr. Chris Heathcote (right) signed a Memorandums of Understanding to establish a strategic cooperation framework to promote infrastructure project financing.

# Corporate Treasury Centres

To further attract multinational companies to establish enterprise financial centers in Hong Kong, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) has collaborated with government authorities to create a favorable tax environment for enterprise financial centers. Specifically, the Tax (Amendment) (No. 2) Ordinance 2016 (Revised tax Regime) was passed in June, allowing companies to deduct interest expenses incurred in operating internal financing activities of their group under specified conditions. Additionally, a 50% reduction in profits tax (i.e., down to 8.25%) applies to profits derived from specified financial services of eligible enterprise financial centers. In addition to legislative work, the HKMA has also been actively promoting the advantages of establishing corporate treasury centres in Hong Kong to multinational and Mainland enterprises. As of the end of the year, the HKMA had contacted nearly 400 companies, financial institutions, and industry organizations. The HKMA also signed a MOU with the Hong Kong China Enterprises Association in November to help Hong Kong-based Chinese-funded enterprises further understand and make greater use of our corporate treasury centre platform.

# Promote Asset Management Services

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority continues to promote Hong Kong as an asset management center. According to the Securities and Futures Commission (SFC), the number of licensed institutions engaged in asset management reached 1,300 by the end of 2016, representing an annual increase of nearly 15%. According to the Asian Venture Capital Journal, the number of private fund companies in Hong Kong (including SFC-licensed and non-SFC-licensed institutions) also increased by 4.6% to 431 in 2016. To date, nearly 70 of the world's top 100 asset management companies, as well as most of the top 20 mutual fund companies in mainland China, have established a presence or affiliated companies in Hong Kong. The number of institutional investors with a presence in Hong Kong is also gradually increasing. Among them, Abu Dhabi Investment Authority, the world's third-largest sovereign wealth fund, announced in October the establishment of an overseas office in Hong Kong – its only office outside of Abu Dhabi.

# Introducing Open-End Fund Corporate Structure

To attract fund registration in Hong Kong, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority continues to collaborate with the government and industry to create a more favorable tax and regulatory environment. In June, the "Securities and Futures (Amendment) Bill 2016" was passed, introducing the open-ended fund company structure, diversifying Hong Kong’s fund registration platform and creating a more flexible operating environment for fund managers, strengthening Hong Kong’s competitiveness as an international asset management center.

# Islamic Finance

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority continues to be committed to increasing market awareness and understanding of Islamic finance, including co-organizing and participating in Islamic finance seminars and talks with industry associations, and sharing experiences with market participants regarding the issuance of Islamic bonds, encouraging them to utilize the Hong Kong platform. # 儲備管理

2016年是充滿意外和黑天鵝事件的一年，環球金融市場出現大波動和震盪。2016年年初市場憂慮內地經濟硬着陸及全球增長放緩，促使環球股市大幅下挫。6月英國脫歐公投和11月美國大選結果亦出人意表。儘管投資環境困難，金管局在過去幾年已採取連串防禦措施，增強外匯基金的抗震能力，因此外匯基金在2016年仍錄得2% 的整體投資回報。

# 外匯基金

根據《外匯基金條例》，外匯基金的首要目的是直接或間接影響港元匯價，亦可運用於保持香港貨幣及金融體系穩定健全，藉此保持香港作為國際金融中心的地位。外匯基金由財政司司長掌有控制權，並投資於其經諮詢外匯基金諮詢委員會後認為合適的證券或其他資產。

# 外匯基金的管理

# 投資目標及組合結構

外匯基金諮詢委員會為外匯基金制定下列投資目標：
(a) 保障資本；
(b) 確保整體貨幣基礎在任何時候都由流通性極高的美元資產提供十足支持；
(c) 確保流動資金足以維持貨幣及金融穩定；以及
(d) 在符合上述(a)至(c)項的前提下盡量爭取投資回報，以保障基金的長期購買力。

以上目標全面顧及外匯基金的法定目的，並已於外匯基金的組合結構及目標資產分布中反映。

外匯基金大致上分成兩個主要組合：支持組合及投資組合。支持組合持有流通性極高的美元資產，按照貨幣發行局制度的規定為貨幣基礎提供十足支持。投資組合主要投資於經濟合作與發展組織成員國的債市及股市，以保障資產的價值及長期購買力。這兩個組合整體債券與股票的長線目標分布比率為71比29。以目標貨幣比重計，91%的資產分配予美元及港元，其餘9%分配予其他貨幣。

為能更妥善管理風險及提高中長期回報，金管局以審慎及循序漸進方式將外匯基金的部分資產分散投資至較多元化的資產類別，包括新興巿場及內地債券與股票、私募股權，以及海外投資物業。新興巿場及內地債券與股票由投資組合持有，私募股權及房地產投資則由長期增長組合持有。長期增長組合的市值上限為外匯基金累計盈餘的三分之一，但因應部分未來基金投放於長期資產，市值上限還有增加的空間。

策略性資產組合於2007年設立，以持有政府基於策略性目的而為外匯基金帳目購入的香港交易及結算所有限公司股份。由於這個組合性質獨特，因此外匯基金的投資表現評估並無將其包括在內。

# 於外匯基金的存款

外匯基金不時接受財政儲備、政府基金及法定組織的存款，利率一般與投資組合的表現掛鈎2，惟未來基金存款則除外。未來基金存款的利率與投資組合及長期增長組合的表現掛鈎，實際利率視乎組合比重而定。於2016年底，未來基金在投資組合與長期增長組合的比重為80：20。預期截至2018年底，未來基金存款中與長期增長組合掛鈎的部分會逐步增加至約50%。

# 投資程序

外匯基金的投資程序分別以策略性資產分布及戰略性資產分布作基礎。策略性資產分布，即投資基準反映的分布情況，顯示外匯基金為達到投資目標而可以作出的最佳長線資產分布。外匯基金以策略性分布作為指引，對資產進行戰略性分布，以爭取超越基準的回報。因此，實際分布往往會與基準分布（亦即策略性分布）有所偏離，而實際與基準分布之間的差距稱為「戰略性偏離」。財政司司長經諮詢外匯基金諮詢委員會後制定投資基準及戰略性偏離的限度，金管局獲授權決定戰略性資產分布。投資組合經理可在戰略性偏離的限度內選持倉盤，從短期市場變化中獲利。

# 投資管理

# 直接投資

金管局儲備管理部職員直接管理外匯基金約74%的投資，其中包括整個支持組合及部分投資組合。該部分投資組合投資於環球定息市場，並透過衍生工具執行外匯基金的宏觀風險管理策略。

# 外聘投資經理

除透過內部職員管理資產外，金管局亦僱用外聘投資經理負責管理外匯基金約26%的資產，其中包括所有上市股票組合及其他特別資產。僱用外聘投資經理的目的，是要運用市場上最佳的專業投資技術為外匯基金投資，並讓外匯基金受惠於多元化的投資方式，以及讓內部專業人員汲取市場知識與資訊。

僱用外聘投資經理的相關支出包括基金管理與託管費、交易費、預扣稅及其他稅項。這些支出主要受市場因素影響而每年不同。

金管局支持證券及期貨事務監察委員會於2016年3月7日發布的《負責任的擁有權原則》（《原則》）。《原則》屬自願性質，旨在協助投資者釐定如何以最佳方法履行其於香港上市公司的投資的擁有權責任。就外匯基金的管理而言，金管局鼓勵獲委任負責管理香港股票組合的外聘基金經理在管理有關投資時採納《原則》。

# 風險管理及監察

近年金融市場波動極大，凸顯風險管理的重要。金管局為內部及外聘投資經理所管理的投資組合均訂立嚴格管控措施及投資指引，並密切監察對指引及法規的遵守情況；另亦採用風險管控工具來評估在正常及極度不利市況下的市場風險。金管局亦進行詳細的投資表現因素分析，務求能最有效地運用內部及外聘投資經理的投資管理技術。

# 2016年的金融市場

2016年環球金融市場出現大波動和震盪。股票市場方面，1月市場憂慮內地經濟硬着陸及全球增長放緩，促使香港及其他主要股市大幅下挫，直至2月中旬市場才穩定下來。6月英國脫歐公投及11月美國大選結果相繼出人意表，但股市在經歷短暫下挫後迅速收復失地。全年計，環球股市普遍表現理想。

# Reserves Management

2016 was a year filled with unexpected events and black swan events, with global financial markets experiencing significant volatility and turbulence. At the beginning of 2016, market concerns over the hard landing of the domestic economy and the slowdown in global growth led to a significant decline in global stock markets. The UK referendum on leaving the EU in June and the US election results in November were also unexpected. Despite the challenging investment environment, the Monetary Authority had implemented a series of defensive measures over the past few years to enhance the resilience of the foreign exchange fund, resulting in a 2% overall investment return for the foreign exchange fund in 2016.

# Exchange Fund

According to the Exchange Fund Ordinance, the primary objective of the Exchange Fund is to influence the exchange rate of the Hong Kong dollar directly or indirectly, and may also be used to maintain the stability and integrity of the monetary and financial system in Hong Kong, thereby maintaining Hong Kong’s position as an international financial centre. The Exchange Fund is controlled by the Financial Secretary and invests in securities or other assets considered appropriate after consulting the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee.

# Foreign exchange fund management.

# Investment objectives and portfolio structure

The Foreign Exchange Fund Advisory Committee has set the following investment objectives for the Foreign Exchange Fund:
(a) To safeguard capital;
(b) To ensure that the overall monetary base is at all times fully backed by highly liquid U.S. dollar assets;
(c) To ensure that sufficient liquidity is available to maintain monetary and financial stability; and
(d) To seek investment returns as far as possible, subject to the above (a) to (c), in order to protect the Fund's long-term purchasing power.

The aforementioned objectives fully take into account the statutory purposes of the foreign exchange fund and have been reflected in the fund's portfolio structure and target asset allocation.

The foreign exchange fund is broadly divided into two main portfolios: supporting portfolio and investment portfolio. The supporting portfolio holds highly liquid U.S. dollar assets, providing ample backing for the currency base as stipulated by the currency issuance system. The investment portfolio primarily invests in the bond and stock markets of member countries of the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development to safeguard asset value and long-term purchasing power. The overall long-term target distribution ratio of bonds and stocks for these two portfolios is 71 to 29. Measured by target currency weighting, 91% of assets are allocated to the U.S. dollar and Hong Kong dollar, with the remaining 9% allocated to other currencies.

To more effectively manage risks and enhance long-term returns, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority is dispersing a portion of the Foreign Exchange Fund's assets into more diversified asset categories in a prudent and gradual manner, including emerging market and mainland bonds and equities, private equity, and overseas real estate investments. Emerging market and mainland bonds and equities are held by the investment portfolio, while private equity and real estate investments are held by the long-term growth portfolio. The market value cap of the long-term growth portfolio is set at one-third of the Foreign Exchange Fund's accumulated surplus, but there is still room for increasing the cap due to some future fund allocations to long-term assets.

The Strategic Asset Portfolio was established in 2007 to hold shares of Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing Limited purchased by the government for strategic purposes under the foreign exchange fund account. Due to its unique nature, the investment performance assessment of the foreign exchange fund does not include this portfolio.

# Deposits in the Foreign Exchange Fund

The Exchange Fund occasionally accepts deposits from the Fiscal Reserves, government funds, and statutory bodies, with interest rates generally linked to the performance of the investment portfolio, except for future fund deposits. The interest rates on future fund deposits are linked to the performance of both the investment portfolio and the long-term growth portfolio, with the actual interest rate depending on the portfolio weighting. As of the end of 2016, the weighting of future fund deposits between the investment portfolio and the long-term growth portfolio was 80:20. It is expected that by the end of 2018, the portion of future fund deposits linked to the long-term growth portfolio will gradually increase to approximately 50%.

# Investment Process

The investment process of the Exchange Fund is based on both strategic asset allocation and tactical asset allocation. Strategic asset allocation, which reflects the investment benchmark, shows the optimal long-term asset allocation that the Exchange Fund can make in order to achieve its investment objectives. The Exchange Fund uses strategic allocation as a guide to carry out tactical allocation in order to seek returns that exceed the benchmark. Therefore, the actual allocation often deviates from the benchmark allocation (i.e., the strategic allocation), and the difference between the actual allocation and the benchmark allocation is referred to as "tactical deviations." The Financial Secretary sets the investment benchmark and the limits of tactical deviations after consulting the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee, and the Hong Kong Monetary Authority is authorized to determine the strategic asset allocation. Portfolio managers can hold positions within the limits of tactical deviations to profit from short-term market fluctuations.

# Investment Management

# Direct Investment

Staff of the Currency Authority's Reserve Management Department directly manage approximately 74% of the Foreign Exchange Fund's investments, including the entire support portfolio and part of the investment portfolio. This portion of the investment portfolio is invested in the global fixed-income market and executes the Foreign Exchange Fund's macro risk management strategy through derivative instruments.

# External Managers

Besides managing assets through internal staff, the Financial Supervisory Commission also hires external investment managers to manage approximately 26% of the foreign exchange fund's assets, including all listed stock portfolios and other special assets. The purpose of hiring external investment managers is to utilize the best professional investment techniques available in the market for the foreign exchange fund's investments, and to allow the foreign exchange fund to benefit from diversified investment approaches, as well as to allow internal professionals to learn market knowledge and information.

The related expenses of hiring an external investment manager include fund management and custody fees, transaction fees, withholding and other taxes. These expenses are primarily influenced by market factors and vary each year.

The HKMA supports the Securities and Futures Ordinance's "Principles of Responsible Ownership" ("Principles"), published by the Securities and Futures Affairs Committee on March 7, 2016. The Principles are voluntary in nature and aim to assist investors in determining how to best fulfill their ownership responsibilities in their investments in Hong Kong-listed companies. In terms of the management of the Exchange Fund, the HKMA encourages externally appointed fund managers responsible for managing Hong Kong equity portfolios to adopt the Principles when managing such investments.

# Risk Management and Compliance

In recent years, financial markets have experienced significant volatility, highlighting the importance of risk management. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) has established strict control measures and investment guidelines for investment portfolios managed by both internal and externally hired investment managers, and closely monitors compliance with these guidelines and regulations. Additionally, the HKMA employs risk management tools to assess market risks under normal and extremely adverse market conditions. The HKMA also conducts a detailed analysis of investment performance factors to ensure the most effective utilization of the investment management capabilities of both internal and external investment managers.

# Foreign exchange fund performance

# The financial markets in 2016.

In 2016, global financial markets experienced significant volatility. Stock markets reacted to concerns in January about a potential economic slowdown in China and globally, leading to sharp declines in Hong Kong and other major markets, which stabilized by mid-February. Unexpected outcomes – the UK’s Brexit referendum in June and the US presidential election in November – initially caused brief downturns, but markets quickly recovered. Overall, global stock markets performed well throughout the year.

In the bond market, further declines in commodity prices in the first quarter deepened concerns about a slowdown in global growth and low inflation. Combined with uncertainties arising from the UK Brexit referendum in the second quarter and market expectations that central banks would maintain loose monetary policies, these factors increased demand for safe assets, supporting the government bond market's strong performance in the first half of 2016. The yield on 10-year US Treasury bonds fell to a historical low of 1.36% in July. However, in the second half of the year, rising market expectations of US interest rate hikes, particularly after the US presidential election, caused US Treasury yields to surge. Yields on other major government bonds also rose, but to a lesser extent.

In the foreign exchange market, the US dollar continued to strengthen in 2016, with the dollar exchange rate index reaching a 14-year high. The dollar's continued strength was supported by the widening interest rate differential between the dollar and other major currencies. Although the yen against the dollar rose by about 3% in 2016, the euro against the dollar fell by about 3%. The pound against the dollar also fell by 16% during the year, marking the largest decline since 2008, amid ongoing uncertainty caused by the Brexit referendum results.

# Foreign exchange fund performance

Despite significant volatility in the financial markets, the Exchange Fund still recorded investment income of HKD 68.1 billion in 2016, including equity income of HKD 28.6 billion from overseas stocks, HKD 5.3 billion from Hong Kong stocks, bond income of HKD 33.1 billion, other investment income of HKD 16.9 billion from investments held by subsidiaries of the Exchange Fund, and a foreign exchange valuation adjustment of HKD 15.8 billion due to non-Hong Kong dollar assets. Due to the sharp rise in the US dollar exchange rate last year, a foreign exchange valuation adjustment was unavoidable when non-US dollar investments of the Exchange Fund were converted to Hong Kong dollars. On the other hand, the strategic asset portfolio recorded a valuation loss of HKD 7 billion.

By the end of 2016, the total assets of the Foreign Exchange Fund reached 36,187 billion Hong Kong dollars. The total market value of long-term growth portfolio investments amounted to 1,818 billion Hong Kong dollars, which included 1,168 billion Hong Kong dollars in private equity and 650 billion Hong Kong dollars in real estate. The total amount committed but not yet drawn down for investment was 1,338 billion Hong Kong dollars.

Despite persistent challenges in the investment environment, the foreign exchange fund still achieved an investment return of 2% in 2016 (excluding strategic asset allocation). The long-term growth portfolio’s annualized internal rate of return since commencing investments in 2009 is approximately 12%.

Due to the continued deterioration of the external investment environment, the Financial Supervisory Commission has made a series of defensive arrangements in recent years, including shortening the maturity of bond portfolios, increasing holdings of cash, and significantly reducing holdings of non-US dollar and non-Hong Kong dollar assets. # 公共傳訊

# 人力資源

金管局聘用、培訓及維持一支專業優秀的工作隊伍，以履行政策目標及靈活應對工作重點的變化。金管局是政府架構的一部分，但按非公務員條款聘請員工，吸引具適當經驗及專門知識的人才。作為公營機構，金管局致力維持精簡靈活的組織架構，並盡可能透過調配現有人手推行新措施及應付不斷增加的工作量。

# 人手編制

金管局於2016年初的人手編制為875人，2016年下半年增設12個職位，以履行金管局在新保險業監管制度下的監管職能。因此，金管局在2016年底的人手編制為887人。

為確保有足夠資源實行新法例和政策、繼續推進須持續的試行項目，以及處理現有日益繁重和複雜的工作，金管局的整體編制於2017年增加40人至927人（增幅4.5%）。新增職位負責執行以下職能：
- 促進銀行及金融體系穩定，包括：
    - 加強監理能力，以管理銀行日益增加的科技風險及新的金融科技項目，以及應對銀行在區內及業務上的擴展；
    - 加強打擊清洗黑錢及恐怖分子資金籌集活動的監管及執法工作，並為2018年打擊清洗黑錢財務特別行動組織相互評估計劃作好準備；
    - 作好實施《金融機構（處置機制）條例》的規劃及籌備工作，以根據國際標準處理金融業「大到不能倒」的問題；及
    - 加強監理能力以配合有關資本及市場風險的新國際標準，並增撥資源處理消費者保障事宜及銀行投訴。
- 因應進一步推動外匯基金投資產品多元化所牽涉的更多投資工作，加強投資、風險管理及其他相關支援，同時強化策略性資產分配及投資程序，以應對挑戰日增的投資環境。
- 制定及實施人才發展計劃，並加強相關資源，確保金管局具備所需的人力資源應對市場發展及未來的挑戰。
- 加強貨幣政策方面的研究及貨幣統計資料的處理，以及提供資源處理就儲值支付工具及零售支付系統的牌照╱指定及相關監管事宜而作出的查詢及投訴。

# 薪酬福利政策及薪酬檢討機制

財政司司長透過外匯基金諮詢委員會聽取其轄下管治委員會提供的意見，並參考市場薪酬水平及做法，決定金管局員工的薪酬及服務條件。薪酬組合包括現金薪酬及公積金，另設一些基本福利。現金薪酬包括每月固定薪酬（即基本薪酬）及根據員工工作表現每年一次過發放的浮動薪酬。

財政司司長每年檢討金管局員工薪酬時，會透過外匯基金諮詢委員會聽取其轄下管治委員會的建議，並考慮管治委員會對金管局過去一年的表現評估、獨立人力資源顧問公司進行的金融業薪酬調查結果，以及其他相關因素。個別工作表現優秀的員工的薪酬亦可能獲得特別調整，以保持其薪酬競爭力。

金管局按個別員工的工作表現，分配獲批准用作調整年度固定薪酬或發放浮動薪酬的款項；而用於專業投資人員的浮動薪酬制度，則旨在加強其投資表現與薪酬的連繫。助理總裁或以上職級員工的固定薪酬調整或浮動薪酬的發放，是由財政司司長經參考管治委員會的意見後批准，有關員工在會議討論到其薪酬的議案時會避席。主管及以下職級員工的固定薪酬調整或浮動薪酬的發放，則由金管局總裁根據財政司司長授權，並按照獲批准用作支付薪酬的整筆款項來決定。

# Corporate Functions

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority maintains effective communication with the community and the market through the media, public education activities and various other channels, enhancing public understanding of the HKMA’s policies and operations. Throughout the year, the HKMA continued to strengthen institutional governance, including promoting staff to enhance their professional capabilities, strictly controlling finances and strengthening information technology security, in order to meet the challenges brought about by the implementation of new measures and an increasingly heavy workload.

# Institutional Development Through Public Engagement

# Public communication

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority maintains close contact with the media to enhance its transparency and improve public understanding of its policies and operations. In 2016, the HKMA held a total of 81 public media events, including 14 press conferences, 13 site visits, and 54 other public events, and arranged 30 media interviews. During the year, 326 bilingual press releases were issued, and numerous media inquiries were handled daily.

Within the year, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) established two important offices: the Infrastructure Financing Facilitation Office (IFFO) and the Fintech Facilitation Office (FFO). To explain the functions and work plans of these offices, the HKMA conducted several public communication initiatives. Additionally, the HKMA held press briefings and seminars to enhance public understanding of its operations and measures in areas such as financial inclusion, Reserves Management, Fintech Supervisory Sandbox, cybersecurity, and small and medium-sized enterprise financing.

Mr. Norman Chan, Governor of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority, met with journalists during his visit to Beijing as part of the Hong Kong Bankers' Association's annual trip in December 2016.

# Public Inquiry

The public enquiry service is an effective channel for citizens to obtain information on the functions and operations of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA). This service handled 10,170 inquiries in 2016, representing a 12% increase compared to 2015. Approximately half of the inquiries concerned banking policies and regulations, monetary and economic issues, and banking consumer matters, particularly banking products and services, the coin collection programme, banking-related guidelines and circulars, stored-value payment tools and retail payment systems, prevention of money laundering and terrorist financing, and prudent regulation of property mortgage loans.

Figure 1 shows the number of public inquiries received each year since 2013, and Figure 2 lists the proportion of different types of inquiries in 2016.

#Publications

In addition to the Annual Report of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA), the HKMA published two issues of the Half-Yearly Monetary and Financial Stability Report and four issues of the Quarterly Report during the year. It also regularly updates the data in the Monthly Statistical Bulletin, providing the latest and in-depth information and analysis on monetary, banking, and economic matters in Hong Kong. Furthermore, the HKMA published 32 inSight articles in 2016, a significant increase from 14 articles in 2015, analyzing various topical issues related to the HKMA's work.

The HKMA "2015 Annual Report" won the Silver Award in the "Non-profit and Charitable Organizations" category in the 2016 Hong Kong Institute of Management's Best Annual Report Awards.

# Public Education Programme

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority Information Centre is located on the 55th floor of International Finance Centre Phase 2, and aims to introduce the work of the HKMA to the public and enhance public understanding of monetary and banking matters. The Information Centre comprises an exhibition hall and a library, and is open to the public for visits and use six days a week. The exhibition hall showcases the work of the HKMA, as well as the development of the monetary and banking sectors in Hong Kong. Reading materials and exhibits are also available for research on Hong Kong’s currency, banking, and financial affairs.

The information center’s policy exhibition area, which explains the work of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority and introduces related financial knowledge, underwent renovation work in the fourth quarter of 2016, enriching the exhibition content and adding a variety of interactive elements. In particular, interactive games that combine learning with play have been added to explain financial concepts in an accessible and engaging manner. There are also visually appealing touch-screen displays that provide a more comprehensive and in-depth introduction to the work of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority, striving to provide visitors with a completely new experience. In addition, the renovated information center features a mosaic artwork depicting the Victoria Harbour skyline, created with over 130,000 Hong Kong coins. The newly revamped policy exhibition area reopened to the public on February 24, 2017.

# Monetary Authority website

The HKMA's institutional website (www.hkma.gov.hk) provides over 50,000 pages of information in English and both traditional and simplified Chinese, conveniently enabling the public to access the latest information from the HKMA. The website also hosts the "Register of Securities Staff of Authorized Institutions" and the "Register of AIs and local Representative offices," maintained under section 20 of the Banking Ordinance, as well as the "Register of SVF licensees," maintained under the Payment Systems and Stored Value Facilities Ordinance. The website features dedicated special pages and prominent quick links to highlight new measures from the HKMA, such as the regulatory regime for stored value facilities (SVFs), IFFO and FFO, and important timely matters, such as warnings about phone scams and the parking locations of coin collection trucks under the Coin Collection Scheme.

The new look of the Information Center's policy exhibition area.

A mosaic depicting the Victoria Harbour skyline created using Hong Kong coins.

The Information Center provides guided tours for visitors. During the year, the Information Center welcomed over 56,200 visitors and provided more than 580 guided tours for schools and other groups (Figure 3). Since its opening in December 2003, the Information Center has cumulatively welcomed over 586,600 visitors.

The library adjacent to the exhibition hall houses over 23,000 books, journals, and other publications for in-depth research on topics such as Hong Kong currency, banking, finance, and central banking. The library also maintains electronic records of authorized institutions and their local representative offices, as well as employees engaged in securities business, as stipulated in Section 20 of the Banking Ordinance.

To maintain close ties with the community and enhance public understanding of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority’s work, the HKMA continues to hold public education seminars. In 2016, the HKMA held three public seminars, attracting over 1,750 secondary school students and teachers. The topics included the linked exchange rate system, Banking Stability, banknotes in Hong Kong, smart tips for using banking products and services, and the Deposit Insurance Scheme. Since these educational seminars were launched in 1998, over 56,400 members of the public have participated.

Students and teachers from various district high schools attended one of the public education lectures.

Figure 3: Types of groups visiting the Information Center in 2016.

# Human resources

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority hires, trains, and maintains a professional and high-caliber workforce to fulfill policy objectives and flexibly respond to changes in work priorities. As part of the government structure, the HKMA hires employees under non-civil service terms to attract talent with appropriate experience and specialized knowledge. As a public institution, the HKMA strives to maintain a streamlined and flexible organizational structure and, as much as possible, implements new measures and handles increasing workloads by reallocating existing staff.

# Hand-crafted

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) had a staffing level of 875 people at the beginning of 2016. In the second half of 2016, 12 additional positions were created to fulfill the HKMA's regulatory functions under the new insurance regulatory regime. Therefore, the HKMA's staffing level was 887 people by the end of 2016.

To ensure sufficient resources for implementing new legislation and policies, continuing ongoing pilot programs, and managing the increasingly complex workload, the Hong Kong Monetary Authority’s (HKMA) overall staffing increased by 40 to 927 in 2017 (an increase of 4.5%). The newly added positions are responsible for the following functions:
- Promoting the stability of the banking and financial system, including:
    - Enhancing supervisory capabilities to manage the increasing technology risks in banks and new fintech initiatives, as well as addressing banks’ expansion within the region and their business operations;
    - Strengthening regulatory and law enforcement efforts to combat money laundering and terrorist financing activities, and preparing for the 2018 Financial Action Task Force mutual evaluation program;
    - Planning and preparing for the implementation of the Financial Institutions (Resolution) ordinance to address the “too big to fail” issue in the financial sector in accordance with international standards; and
    - Enhancing supervisory capabilities to align with new international standards on capital and market risks, and allocating additional resources to handle consumer protection matters and bank complaints.
- Strengthening investment, risk management, and related support in response to the increased investment work involved in further diversifying the Exchange Fund’s investment portfolio, while enhancing strategic asset allocation and investment processes to cope with the increasingly challenging investment environment.
- Developing and implementing talent development programs and strengthening related resources to ensure the HKMA has the necessary human resources to address market developments and future challenges.
- Strengthening research on monetary policy and the processing of monetary statistics, as well as providing resources to handle inquiries and complaints regarding the licensing/designation and related regulation of stored value payment tools and retail payment systems.

The HKMA allocates temporary resources to handle other tasks and lends staff to international or local institutions, such as the IMF (IMF) and the Financial Development Bureau, to assist with work or policies related to Hong Kong or the HKMA. Additionally, the HKMA assigns staff to the Hong Kong Deposit Protection Corporation and the Financial and Treasury Bureau's Market Association to provide full-time or supportive operational support.

# Compensation and Benefits Policy and Compensation Review Mechanism

The Financial Secretary determines the salaries and service conditions of Hong Kong Monetary Authority employees by seeking opinions from its governing committees through the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee, and taking into account market salary levels and practices. The compensation package includes cash compensation and a mandatory provident fund, along with some basic benefits. Cash compensation comprises a fixed monthly salary (i.e., basic salary) and a variable salary paid annually based on employee performance.

The Financial Secretary reviews the salaries of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) staff annually, and will hear recommendations from its Exchange Fund Advisory Committee, taking into account the governance committee's assessment of the HKMA’s performance over the past year, the results of a compensation survey of the financial industry conducted by an independent human resources consulting firm, and other relevant factors. The salaries of individual employees with outstanding performance may also be adjusted to maintain their compensation competitiveness.

The Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) allocates funds approved for adjusting annual fixed salaries or disbursing variable pay to individual employees based on their individual work performance. The variable pay system for professional investment staff is designed to strengthen the link between their investment performance and their compensation. Adjustments to fixed salaries or disbursement of variable pay for employees at the level of Deputy Governor or above are approved by the Financial Secretary after consulting the Governance Committee. Such employees will be absent from meetings when their salary proposals are discussed. For employees at the level of Director or below, adjustments to fixed salaries or disbursement of variable pay are decided by the HKMA Governor, based on the lump sum approved for salary payments, under the authority delegated by the Financial Secretary.

其餘5%的該等金融資產的公平值，是以估值方法估計，而所用的參數並非以可觀察市場數據為基礎（第3級參數）。有關金融資產共1,758.86億港元，主要包括非上市投資基金。

# 金融管理專員及外匯基金諮詢委員會轄下的審核委員會就財務報表而須承擔的責任

金融管理專員須負責按照香港會計師公會頒布的《香港財務報告準則》及行政長官在《外匯基金條例》第7條下所發出的指示擬備真實而公平的財務報表，及落實其認為必要的內部控制，使財務報表不存有因欺詐或錯誤而導致的重大錯誤陳述。

在擬備財務報表時，金融管理專員須負責評估集團持續經營的能力， 以及在適用情況下披露與持續經營有關的事項，並以持續經營作為會計基礎。

外匯基金諮詢委員會轄下的審核委員會負責監督集團的財務報告過程。

# 審計師就財務報表審計而須承擔的責任

我的目標是就整體財務報表是否不存有任何因欺詐或錯誤而導致的重大錯誤陳述取得合理保證，並發出包括我意見的審計師報告。合理保證是高水平的保證，但不能確保按審計署審計準則進行的審計定能發現所存有的任何重大錯誤陳述。錯誤陳述可以由欺詐或錯誤引起，如果合理預期它們個別或滙總起來可能影響財務報表使用者所作出的經濟決定，則會被視作重大錯誤陳述。

在根據審計署審計準則進行審計的過程中，我會運用專業判斷並秉持專業懷疑態度。我亦會：
- 識別和評估因欺詐或錯誤而導致財務報表存有重大錯誤陳述的風險；設計及執行審計程序以應對這些風險；以及取得充足和適當的審計憑證，作為我意見的基礎。由於欺詐可能涉及串謀、偽造、蓄意遺漏、虛假陳述，或凌駕內部控制的情況，因此未能發現因欺詐而導致重大錯誤陳述的風險，較未能發現因錯誤而導致者為高；
- 了解與審計相關的內部控制，以設計適當的審計程序。然而，此舉並非旨在對集團內部控制的有效性發表意見；
- 評價金融管理專員所採用的會計政策是否恰當，以及其作出的會計估計和相關資料披露是否合理；
- 判定金融管理專員以持續經營作為會計基礎的做法是否恰當，並根據所得的審計憑證，判定是否存在與事件或情況有關，而且可能對集團持續經營的能力構成重大疑慮的重大不確定性。如果我認為存在重大不確定性，則有必要在審計師報告中請使用者留意財務報表中的相關資料披露。假若所披露的相關資料不足，我便須發出非無保留意見的審計師報告。我的結論是基於截至審計師報告日止所取得的審計憑證。然而，未來事件或情況可能導致集團不能繼續持續經營；
- 評價財務報表的整體列報方式、結構和內容，包括披露資料，以及財務報表是否公允反映交易和事項；及
- 就集團中實體或業務活動的財務資料獲取充足和適當的審計憑證，以對財務報表發表意見。我負責指導、監督和執行集團審計。我對我的審計意見承擔全部責任。

我會與外匯基金諮詢委員會轄下的審核委員會溝通計劃的審計範圍和時間以及重大審計發現等事項，包括我在審計期間識別出內部控制的任何重大缺陷。

# Exchange Fund

# Report by the Audit Office Director

# Hong Kong Special Administrative Region Government Survey and Mapping Office

# Independent Auditor's Report to the Financial Secretary

# Opinion

I hereby certify that I have audited the financial statements of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority and its subsidiaries ("the Group") contained in pages 149 to 237, which include the balance sheets of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority and the Group as at December 31, 2016, the income statements, statement of comprehensive income, statement of changes in equity, cash flow statements, and the notes to the financial statements, including a summary of significant accounting policies, for the year ended on that date.

I believe that the financial statements have fairly and adequately reflected, in accordance with the Hong Kong Financial Reporting Standards issued by the Hong Kong Institute of Accountants, the financial position of the Exchange Fund and the Group as at December 31, 2016, and their financial performance and cash flows for the year then ended, and have been properly prepared in accordance with the instructions issued by the Chief Executive under Section 7 of the Exchange Fund Ordinance (Chapter 66).

# The basis of opinion.

I have conducted the audit in accordance with the instructions issued by the Chief Executive under Section 7 of the Exchange Fund Ordinance and the auditing standards of the Audit Department. The responsibilities I must bear according to these standards are detailed in this report's section "Responsibilities of the Auditor Regarding the Audit of Financial Statements." According to these standards, I am independent of the group and have fulfilled other ethical responsibilities in accordance with these standards. I believe that the audit evidence I have obtained is sufficient and appropriate to provide a basis for my audit opinion.

# Key Audit Matter

Key audit matters are those matters that, in my professional judgment, were most important to the audit of the financial statements for the year ended December 31, 2016. I addressed these matters in auditing the financial statements as a whole and forming my opinion, but I do not express a separate opinion on these matters.

# Auditor General's Report (Continued)

# Key Audit Matter

How should I handle relevant matters during an audit?

# Valuation of Financial Assets and Financial Liabilities Measured at Fair Value

Please refer to the notes to the financial statements, Sections 2.5, 2.6, and 36.1.

As of December 31, 2016, the Group's financial assets, booked at fair value, totaled 31,989.75 billion HKD, while financial liabilities totaled 9,639.77 billion HKD.

95% of the fair values of such financial assets and all such financial liabilities are based on quoted prices for the same assets or liabilities in active markets (level 1 inputs), or estimated using valuation techniques, and the parameters used are based on observable market data (level 2 inputs).

The fair value of the remaining 5% of such financial assets is estimated using valuation techniques, and the parameters used are not based on observable market data (level 3 inputs). The total amount of such financial assets is HKD 17,588.6 million, mainly consisting of unlisted investment funds.

Given the significant amounts involved and the reliance on estimates, the valuation of financial assets and financial liabilities measured at fair value is a key audit matter.

The audit procedures for the valuation of financial assets and liabilities measured at fair value include:
- Understanding the valuation processes for different categories of financial assets and liabilities, including related monitoring measures;
- Evaluating and testing the monitoring measures, including related application controls for computer systems;
- Obtaining confirmations regarding the valuation, existence, rights and obligations, and completeness of financial assets and liabilities;
- Verifying prices based on independent sources if market quotations are used;
- Evaluating the appropriateness of the valuation methods and the reasonableness of related assumptions, as well as verifying the parameters based on independent sources, if the parameters used in the valuation methods are based on observable market data; and
- Evaluating the appropriateness of the valuation methods and the reasonableness of related assumptions and parameters if the parameters used in the valuation methods are not based on observable market data.

# Future fund deposits

Please refer to Notes 2.6, 2.16.1, 4(b), 23, and 28 of the financial statements.

In previous years, the majority of deposits in the fiscal reserve were required to be repaid upon request, and interest was calculated at a fixed interest rate determined annually based on the past investment returns of the investment portfolio.

The government established the Future Fund within the fiscal reserves on January 1, 2016. The Future Fund’s deposits include initial funding from the Land Fund surplus (amounting to HK$219.73 billion) and regular contributions transferred from the government’s general revenue account (the amount of which is directed by the Financial Secretary). Interest on the Future Fund’s deposits is calculated based on a composite interest rate, which is determined annually on a weighted average basis, referencing a fixed interest rate linked to the performance of the investment portfolio mentioned above and an annual return rate linked to the performance of the long-term growth portfolio (holding private equity and real estate investments). Unless otherwise directed by the Financial Secretary, the deposits of the Future Fund, together with any accrued interest, should be repaid by December 31, 2025.

As of December 31, 2016, the Future Fund held a total of HK$224.53 billion in deposits. The accumulated interest earned on these deposits was HK$10.071 billion. Due to the large amounts involved and significant changes in the deposit terms, particular attention needs to be paid to the measurement, presentation, and disclosure of information regarding these deposits and the interest earned.

For future fund deposits, the audit procedures include:
- Evaluating whether the accounting policies used for measuring the deposits and the interest earned are appropriate;
- Reviewing the calculation method of the annual return rate linked to the performance of the long-term growth portfolio;
- Verifying the calculation of the fixed interest rate based on the past performance of the investment portfolio, the annual return rate linked to the long-term growth portfolio, and the composite interest rate based on these two rates;
- Verifying the amount of accrued interest calculated using the composite interest rate; and
- Reviewing the presentation method and disclosure information of the deposits and interest earned in the financial statements.

# Valuation of Investment Properties Measured at Fair Value

Please refer to Notes 2.12, 17, and 18 of the financial statements.

The Group's investment properties are accounted for at fair value, totaling HK$22.723 billion as of December 31, 2016. The Group also holds interests in 3 joint ventures and 14 associate companies, which mainly engage in holding overseas investment properties. The aggregate value of these interests amounts to HK$32.083 billion. The fair values of these investment properties, whether directly held by the Group or by joint ventures or associate companies, are primarily determined by independent professional valuers. These valuations involve significant judgments and estimates, including the valuation methods and assumptions used.

Regarding the valuation of investment properties measured at fair value, the audit procedures include:
- Obtaining and reviewing valuation reports for investment properties directly held by the Group or held by associates or joint ventures, and verifying that fair value is determined based on the valuation as stated in the relevant valuation reports;
- Assessing the independence and qualifications of the valuers; and
- Evaluating whether the valuation methods are appropriate, and whether the related assumptions and parameters are reasonable.

# Other materials

The Financial Controller is responsible for other information. This other information includes all information in the 2016 Annual Report of the Financial Services Commission, except for the financial statements and my auditor's report.

My opinion on the financial statements does not include other information, and I do not provide any form of attestation conclusion on other information.

Regarding the audit of financial statements, I have a responsibility to read other information in order to consider whether such information is materially inconsistent with the financial statements or with circumstances known to me during the audit process, or appears to contain material misstatements. Based on the work I have performed, if I conclude that other information contains material misstatements, I need to report that fact. In this regard, I have nothing to report.

# Responsibilities of the financial controller and the Audit Committee under the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee with respect to financial statements.

The Financial Management Officer must be responsible for preparing true and fair financial statements in accordance with the Hong Kong Financial Reporting Standards (HKFRSs) promulgated by the Hong Kong Institute of Certified Public Accountants, and the instructions issued by the Chief Executive under section 7 of the Exchange Fund Ordinance. The officer must also implement internal controls deemed necessary to ensure that the financial statements do not contain material misstatements resulting from fraud or error.

When preparing financial statements, financial management officers are responsible for assessing the group’s ability to continue as a going concern, and for disclosing matters related to going concern where applicable, and using the going concern basis of accounting.

The Audit Committee under the Foreign Exchange Fund Advisory Committee is responsible for overseeing the Group’s financial reporting process.

# Auditors bear responsibilities regarding the audit of financial statements.

My objective is to obtain reasonable assurance that the financial statements as a whole do not contain any material misstatements resulting from fraud or error, and to issue an auditor's report that includes my opinion. Reasonable assurance is a high level of assurance, but it does not guarantee that an audit conducted in accordance with the audit standards of the audit office will necessarily detect any material misstatements that may exist. A misstatement may be caused by fraud or error, and it is considered material if it is reasonably expected that it, individually or in aggregate, could influence the economic decisions made by users of the financial statements.

During the audit process conducted in accordance with the Audit Office's auditing standards, I will apply professional judgment and maintain a professional skeptical attitude. I will also:  
- Identify and assess the risk of material misstatements in the financial statements due to fraud or error; design and perform audit procedures to address these risks; and obtain sufficient and appropriate audit evidence to support my opinion. Since fraud may involve collusion, falsification, intentional omission, false statements, or overriding of internal controls, the risk of not detecting material misstatements due to fraud is higher than the risk of not detecting those due to error;  
- Understand the internal controls relevant to the audit in order to design appropriate audit procedures. However, this is not intended to express an opinion on the effectiveness of the group's internal controls;  
- Evaluate whether the accounting policies adopted by the Financial Management Officer are appropriate, and whether the accounting estimates and related disclosures made are reasonable;  
- Determine whether the Financial Management Officer's use of the going concern basis for accounting is appropriate, and based on the audit evidence obtained, determine whether there are significant uncertainties related to events or circumstances that may cast significant doubt on the group's ability to continue as a going concern. If I believe that significant uncertainty exists, it is necessary to draw the users' attention to the relevant disclosures in the financial statements in the auditor's report. If the disclosures are insufficient, I will issue an auditor's report with a non-unqualified opinion. My conclusion is based on the audit evidence obtained up to the date of the auditor's report. However, future events or circumstances may lead to the group's inability to continue as a going concern;  
- Evaluate the overall presentation, structure, and content of the financial statements, including disclosures, and whether the financial statements fairly present the transactions and events; and  
- Obtain sufficient and appropriate audit evidence regarding the financial information of entities or business activities within the group in order to express an opinion on the financial statements. I am responsible for directing, supervising, and performing the group audit. I bear full responsibility for my audit opinion.

I will communicate with the Audit Committee under the Exchange Fund Advisory Committee regarding the scope and timeline of the plan’s audit, as well as significant audit findings, including any material deficiencies in internal controls that I identify during the audit.
